title: If Edward VIII did not abdicate, would Elizabeth be the monarch today? - Quora

response.answer_text: Upon King Edward VIII’s succession to the throne in 1936, the first five people in the line of succession to the British monarchy was as follows: Prince Albert, Duke of York - later King George VIPrincess Elizabeth of York - later Queen Elizabeth IIPrincess Margaret of York - later Princess Margaret, Countess of SnowdonPrince Henry, Duke of GloucesterPrince George, Duke of KentWHAT REALLY HAPPENED: King Edward VIII, who was infertile and therefore had no children, abdicated the throne in 1936. Upon his abdication, Prince Albert, his younger brother and heir to the throne, became King George VI. When King George VI died in 1952, his daughter—Princess Elizabeth, Duchess of Edinburgh—became Queen Elizabeth II. However, Elizabeth was never regarded as the heiress apparent, because there was the possibility that King George VI could have a son, who would then become heir apparent, due to male primogeniture. ALTERNATE HISTORY #1: If King Edward VIII hadn’t abdicated, he would have been the British monarch until his death in 1972. Because Prince Albert died in 1952, Princess Elizabeth would’ve become heiress apparent, and she would’ve been King Edward VIII’s successor. ALTERNATE HISTORY #2: King Edward VIII was fertile and married a British woman instead of Wallis Simpson. He had only one child, a son named William, who succeeded his father in 1972. King William V is the ruling monarch today, and his son, Prince Henry, is the heir apparent, followed by his two daughters, neither of whom have children. Meanwhile, Princess Elizabeth would be fourth in the line of succession. She would obviously not have the status she does today—in fact, she probably wouldn’t be very important at all, and her chances of becoming Queen would be zero. She would still be known as the Duchess of Edinburgh. In real life, she would be about the equivalent of Prince Andrew, Duke of York. Who? Exactly.

The line of succession (before 2013 and applies to everyone born before 2011) worked like this: Eldest sonHis descendantsOlder son before younger sonSons before daughtersOlder daughter before younger daughterOther sonsOlder before youngerTheir descendantsOlder son’s children before younger son’s childrenOlder sons before younger sonsSons before daughtersOlder daughters before younger daughtersOlder daughter of the monarchHer descendantsOlder sons before younger sonsSons before daughtersOlder daughters before younger daughtersYounger daughter of the monarchHer descendantsOlder sons before younger sonsSons before daughtersOlder daughters before younger daughtersEldest younger brother of the monarchOther younger brothers of the monarchOlder before youngerSister of the monarchOlder before youngerDescendants of a sibling of the monarchOlder younger brother’s children before younger younger brother’s childrenBrother’s children before sister’s childrenAmong these children: Older sons before younger sons, sons before daughters, older daughters before younger daughtersEldest uncle of the monarchOther uncles of the monarchAunt of the monarchA distant relative (the one that’s closest inherits)Whether Elizabeth would have been the monarch today depends on a lot of things: Would the monarchy survive? Would Edward VIII have children if he didn’t abdicate? Would George VI have lived longer if he didn’t become king in 1936? If George VI didn’t become king in 1936, would he have went on having more children?
